Award.AbstractNarration: This award is made as part of the FY 2015 Mathematical Sciences Postdoctoral Research Fellowships Program. Each of the fellowships supports a research and training project at a host institution in the mathematical sciences, including applications to other disciplines, under the mentorship of a sponsoring scientist. The title of the project for this fellowship to Jeffrey Galkowski is "Scattering by thin barriers and quantum ergodicity for mixed systems." The host institution for the fellowship is Stanford University, and the sponsoring scientist is Dr. Andras Vasy.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The grant DMS-1502661 resulted in twenty publications and preprints and helped to organize an important summer school in semiclassical analysis. 

Intellectual Merit: The research produced from this project falls into several projects. The first project unified the treatment of sup norms norms and averages for Laplace eigenfunctions, extended and improved all known bounds on sup norms and averages, and resulted in the first quantitative improvements under dynamical assumptions.

The next project studied the L^2 behavior of restrictions of eigenfunctions to hypersurfaces. One paper gave sharp upper bounds on the growth of an eigenfunction hear the glancing set and another paper proved unique continuation type lower bounds for Cauchy data on open subsets of hypersurfaces. Moreover, under a geometric control assumption these unique continuation type lower bounds can be replaced by uniform lower bounds. These results also produce null-controllability for the heat and wave equations from a hypersurface.

The next project concerns quantum chaos and showed that every Laplace operator is arbitrarily close (in a certain operator norm) to being quantum unique ergodic. That is, to an operator all of whose eigenfunctions distribute uniformly on the cosphere bundle.

The next project cocerns the Steklov problem and studies the interior behavior of Steklov eigenfunctions. The first article proved a conjecture of Hislop--Lutzer on the decay of Steklov eigenfunctions; harmonic extensions of eigenfunctions of the Dirichlet to Neuamann map on a manifold with boundary. The next article considered the two dimensional case and show that these harmonic extensions typically oscillate very slowly away from the boundary. 

The next two projects concern scattering theory. The first, concerns resolvent and resonance bounds scattering on general manifolds. This project, consisting of three articles, produced sharp estimates sharp estimates on resonance free regions when singularities escape at a fixed rate, the first fractal Weyl laws on the number of resonances for general trapping, and optimal bounds on resolvents for non-trapping manifolds.

The next project, consisting of two articles, concerns scattering on manifolds with singular geometry: manifolds with cone points, and transmission problems. In the former case we studied when cone points do not diffract waves i.e. situations where the cone point cannot be seen by the singularities of solutions to the wave equation. We proved that the only such examples in the real analytic setting have periodic geodesic flow with period 2\pi. In one and two dimensions, only quotients of the unit sphere are possible.  The main result of the article concerning transmission problems is to give a mathematical proof of a model, used to design acoustics in concert halls since the founding of acoustical architecture by W.C. Sabine in the late 1800's, is not only mathematically justified but cannot be improved in general. Moreover, this model applies to a variety of transmission problems including the transparent obstacle problem.

Broader impacts:

During the term of NSF award DMS-1502661, the PI spent a great deal of effort on teaching and scientific dissemination. The PI collaborated with 9 people from 4 countries, the U.S., Canada, the U. K. and France. The PI taught 9 courses at the undergraduate and graduate levels and began work on a set of notes on Microlocal Analysis for Boundary Value Problems; a subject for which there are very few references. 

The PI collaborated with experts in numerical analysis of high frequency scattering. During these collaborations the PI learned about the tools of numerical analysis and helped these experts to learn about semiclassical analysis. Semiclassical tools proved very useful for this community and as a result, Euan Spence has hired a postdoc in semiclassical analysis and PI Galkowskivis included in Spence's successful EPSRC Early Career Fellowship application as a long term visitor. 

In addition, the PI gave more than 30 research talks including 12 invited talks at international conferences and organized a major summer school in semiclassical analysis with more than 110 attendees at the undergraduate, graduate, and postdocoral level.
